title: Fix incorrectly advertised numpy 1.x support (numpy2 is required now)

labels.name: 🪳 bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: sdk-python
labels.description: Python logging API

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: concerning crates, pip packages etc

body:
### Related

* Fixes https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/9862

### What

The rerun python sdk incorrectly advertised being compatible with numpy 1.x when in actuallity we unintentionally made numpy 2 mandatory in 0.23.0. This changes make numpy 2.0.0 the minimum requirement.

(The only _known_ piece that introduced the dependency is that we started using the `copy` parameter of `asarray` which is only available in numpy 2)

labels.name: exclude from changelog

body:
* See https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/9816 for more information

To test:
```
pixi run rerun rrd migrate <0.22.x file>
uv run --with rerun-sdk==0.23.1 rerun <migrated file>
```

We should be able to load on 0.23.1, which can't load 0.22.1 (and earlier) files.

title: Query cache is now aware of component tags, `latest_at` queries can opt-in to full tags

labels.name: 🚜 refactor
labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
### Related

* Another part of #6889 

### What

Next step toward tagged components in the Viewer. Major changes in this iteration:
* query cache internally uses `ComponentDescriptor` rather than `ComponentName` as its key
* latest_at method on the query cache can be used with _either_ component name or descriptor queries. component name queries behave as before and pick the first (think: random, indetermined) matching descriptor whereas exact descriptor based queries are now _exact_. This allows us to opt-in to fully tagged queries bit by bit. **Note:** `ComponentName` behavior is temporary! If we want component name based queries in the future their resulting selection should not be "random" as it is right now!
* latest_at indexes now indexed over `ComponentDescriptor` rather `ComponentName`
* some related tests now use tagged queries. Added a test for "exact" latest_at queries.

note that the less common range queries haven't been adjusted yet, but cache keys are still descriptor based

title: Improve and mitigate warnings around dataloss when flushing

labels.name: 🪵 Log & send APIs
labels.description: Affects the user-facing API for all languages

body:
### Related

* Closes #9818.

### What

> [!IMPORTANT]
> This PR also changes the way `RecordingStream` is free'd in the C/C++ API. Before we called `stream.disconnect`, which unnecessarily replaced the current sink with a _buffered_ sink that would be immediately dropped afterwards. Not only did this cause spam in the log outputs, it also lead to race conditions upon (log) application shutdown.

This PR makes it more explicit why we drop data during flushing, by bumping the log messages to `warn!`. It also improves the message by pointing the users to `flush_timeout`.

We also bump the default timeout from two seconds to now 3 seconds.

It's worth taking note that explicitly calling `flush_blocking` from our SDKs should be able to opt-out of this timeout, to ensure all data is sent. This will be tracked here:

* #9845.

title: Update mac runners to `macos-15` and use clang 18

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
### Related

- Fix CI regression introduced by #9764 

### What

#9764 pulls DataFusion to the wasm target, and old clang version struggle to deal with it (LLVM error: section too large"). In particular, it fails with the mac runners, which default to clang 15. So this PR:
- updates mac runners to 15, which include (optional) llvm 18 (note that `macos-latest` points at `macos-14`, which isn't quite the latest)
- enables llvm 18 (the default is still 15)

title: Make store aware of full component descriptors

labels.name: 🚜 refactor
labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
### Related

* Another shaky step towards #6889 

### What

Makes `re_chunk_store` (and more methods of `re_chunk`) fully aware of `ComponentDescriptor` and have most of its operations operate on `CompontentDesriptor` rather than `ComponentName`. 

For this not to ripple out to every corner I had to patch various places, most notably `re_query` and everything relating dataframe queries, to still work with component names meanwhile. Note that some of this might incur a temporary performance cost!

Some callsites have already been fully ported:
* `re_chunk_store_ui`
* `re_time_panel`, bar its `Item::ComponentPath` links which don't understand descriptors yet

Chunkbrowser after - notice that it lists components with full descriptor now
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/91650923-9350-48e1-950c-5794c3c2bb26)

See lengthy title. The `rerun` crate is supposed to be the only crate you ever need, even when doing viewer extensions. However, over time we eroded a bit and in many situations it was necessary to import other crates.
This PR fixes this and tightens the crates that our examples depend on.

title: Remove component name indirection from `ChunkComponents`

labels.name: 🚜 refactor
labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
### Related

* Tiny prep piece for the next step on https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/6889

### What

After talking with @teh-cmc a bit we decided that we want to do Desc -> data/etc. maps everywhere instead of adding an indirection for component names. The latter has advantages since there are plenty situations where we want to make statements about all columns with a given component name. However, it makes a lot of things a lot more complex and the indirection is likely harmful for small numbers of columns per chunk, i.e. it becomes a bit of a muddy tradeoff.

This also happens to be a great sightseeing task for me to get started with getting queries and the viewer at large over to be working with fully tagged components.

title: Direct API for setting blueprint on a notebook-embedded viewer

labels.name: sdk-python
labels.description: Python logging API

labels.name: notebook
labels.description: Jupyter notebooks etc

body:
### What

This is a more ergonomic approach to using https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/9506 for blueprints.

This lets you use Blueprint objects directly without needing to save out to `.rbl` files.

Example:
```
blueprint = rrb.Spatial3DView(contents="/**")
viewer = rr.notebook.Viewer(width=1350, height=800, url="rerun+http://localhost:51234")
viewer.set_application_blueprint("DROID", blueprint)
viewer.display()
```

title: Refactor entity filtering in heuristics

labels.name: 🚜 refactor
labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: heuristics
labels.description: Heuristics for placing views, fallback provider, etc.

body:
* Follow-up to https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/9785

I cleaned up the code in several ways:
* More clear naming
* Use a _inclusive_ filter to match stdlib (`retain`, `filter`) and to avoid double negatives
* Use a `dyn Fn` for future flexibility
* Simplified code around uses of `any/all` iterators (and maybe fixed some bugs?)
* Use `ViewSpawnHeuristics::empty` instead of `default` to be more explicit

labels.name: feat-graph-view

body:
* Closes https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/9781

The filter contains entities which _should not_ create views, but the filter was used to determine which entities _should_ turn into views. It only contains `+ /__properties/**`, so it could never match anything.

I believe `then_some` as a concept is at fault here, this should've been an `if` from the start :grimacing:

title: Fix and improve spatial view heuristics

labels.name: 🪳 bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: 🦟 regression
labels.description: A thing that used to work in an earlier release

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: heuristics
labels.description: Heuristics for placing views, fallback provider, etc.

body:
### Related
* Closes https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/9774
* Bug introduced in https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/9439
* and maybe https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/9308
* …and other PRs that happened since last release

### Checklist
* [x] Fixed `tests/python/release_checklist/check_heuristics_mixed_2d_and_3d.py`
* [x] Fixed `tests/python/release_checklist/check_heuristics_mixed_all_root.py`
* [x] Fixed `tests/python/release_checklist/check_heuristics_2d.py` (and replaced it)
* [x] Fix failing snapshot test
* [x] Run heuristics on all examples
  * Discovered unrelated bugs
  * https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/9781
  * https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/9782

### What
Added a bunch of `insta` snapshot tests for the 2D spatial view heuristics, replacing a few manual release checklists tests.

I found several bugs in the heuristics. I think they make a lot more sense now in theory and in practice.


### Changed behavior
Previously, if we logged two images at `foo` and `foo/bar`, they would _always_ be added to the same view (stacked), even if they were both color images, and even if they were of different resolutions.

Now we _only_ overlap images if they are the same resolution, AND there is at most ONE color image (including videos) and ONE depth image.

I think that makes much more sense.

* part of https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/9741

### What

This PR introduces `DataFusionTableWidget`, a widget capable of displaying a table in a datafusion session context, along with the necessary changes to use it for partition table display in the redap browser.

Notes:
- The core piece is the `DataFusionAdapter`, which triggers and track completion of datafusion queries (which are async), and uses egui memory to save state across frames.
- A `TableBlueprint` stuff makes an appearance. This eventually leads to the discussion of manipulating them from code, etc.
- The pre-existing `TableConfig` remains. At first sight, it seems that it should be merged with `DataFusionAdapter`, since both construct implement manipulation of the dataframe being displayed. There are good reason to keep them separate though:
  - It makes sense to keep column visibility/order at the RecordBatch/UI level and outside of the (slower) datafusion loop.
  - Eventually, I would like that logic to be implemented directly into `egui_table`, since it is potentially useful for any table user.
- Likewise, there is a small `Columns` helper. This one will definitely be merged with `TableConfig` as soon as the other use of `TableConfig` are replaced by `DataFusionTableWidget` (namely: the in-viewer table).

### Next steps
- Test the release
- If this is an 'alpha' release, you can just merge the pull request.
- Otherwise:
  - For any added commits, run the release workflow in 'rc' mode again
  - After testing, _ensure that this PR is mergeable to _, then run the release workflow in 'release' mode
  - Once the final release workflow finishes it will create a GitHub release for you. Then:
    - [ ] Sanity check the build artifacts:
      - [x] pip install: does it install and run?
      - [ ] cargo install of cli tool: does it install and run?
      - [x] C++ SDK zip: does it contain rerun_c for all platforms?
    - [ ] Populate the release with the changelog and a nice header video/picture, check , then click .
    - [ ] Update the [google colab notebooks](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1R9I7s4o6wydQC_zkybqaSRFTtlEaked_) to install this version and re-execute the notebook.

A few hours after the GitHub release is created,  will create a
[conda feedstock PR](https://github.com/conda-forge/rerun-sdk-feedstock/pulls).
Make sure Jeremy is on top of it!

- [ ] Tests

title: Compare snippets to legacy rrds

labels.name: 🔨 testing
labels.description: testing and benchmarks

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
## Related
* Requires https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/9750
* Part of #9110

## What
This restructures the folder of .rrds that we use for backwards-compatibility checks, so that it has a `snippets` folder, matching the structure of our snippets. These are then read by `compare_snippets_output.py` and are compared to the latest output of the snippets. They should be equal to each other (since the old .rrds should be migrated on ingestion).

### Consequences
If we add a new snippet, the CI will fail until the output .rrd of that snippet is checked in to CI (using `compare_snippets_output.py --write-missing-backward-assets`)

If we _change_ a snippet (so that it outputs something different), we need to either:
* Update the file on `git lfs`
* Add a _new_ file to `git lfs` alongside the old one
* Add an opt-out flag for comparing to the file on `git lfs` to `snippets.toml`

Since this should be a rather rare occurrence (our snippets tend to stay pretty stable), any one solution will do, and I have not decided on one yet. Maybe cross that bridge if and when we get to it?

title: Do not output empty vec from `BinaryStream::read`

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
This results in downstream consumers (gradio) getting "data source left unexpectedly", caused by the yielded bytes being empty, and thus also without a header, which causes the parser to fail. Doesn't cause any trouble, but produces an annoying and unnecessary warning.

`yield stream.read()` where `stream.read()` returns `None` will result in Gradio not outputting anything, so we return `None` instead of an empty `Vec`. This felt like the lowest risk fix.

labels.name: ui
labels.description: concerns graphical user interface

body:
### Related

* closes https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/9520

### What

This PR changes the behaviours of the entity search filter when the search is activated but the query is still empty. Now, the displayed content is unchanged compared to when the search is inactive. Previously, nothing would be displayed in that situation. This required subtle change of when a session id is returned, such that the collapse state used in the active-but-empty-query state is the same as in the inactive state.

title: rerun_py: adapt the `register` API to the new asynchronous nature of  `register_with_dataset`

labels.name: sdk-python
labels.description: Python logging API

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: dataplatform
labels.description: Rerun Data Platform integration

body:
### Related

* Related to: https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/issues/527
* Follows:
  * https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/9537
  * https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/pull/543 

### What
In https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/pull/543, we replaced the synchronous register_with_dataset endpoint with an
asynchronous equivalent. The python client, however, expects the
endpoint to be synchronous.

This change is a quick-fix to make the python client block for dataset
registration task completion so that current user should not feel the
difference.

We should improve this in the future by exposing the asynchronous nature
of the endpoint directly to the client.

title: Improve view heuristics for time series plot

labels.name: 📺 re_viewer
labels.description: affects re_viewer itself

body:
### Related
* Closes https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/9521
* Related to  #4926

### What
We added a new `/spiral` entity with time series data to our plot demo.
This hit a wird corner-case of our heuristics.

I believe the heuristic is meant for the case when you log a few top-level entities, e.g. `/x`, `/y`, `/z` and that we in that case should put them all in the same plot.

…however, I'm not sure we want or need that anymore, now that you can log multiple scalars with the new `rr.Scalars`.

But, instead of completely removing the heuristic I refined it to be more conservative in when it triggers.

title: Format random IDs withour dashes

labels.name: 🧑‍💻 dev experience
labels.description: developer experience (excluding CI)

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
### Related
* Part of https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/issues/250

### What
We sometimes use a string-formatted UUIDv4 as a random ID. I think it's better we skip the dashes in these cases, so that we can double-click-to-select.

Before: `0840159d-1af9-48fb-8d14-208e388b26ee`
After: `0840159d1af948fb8d14208e388b26ee`

For AppId I also decided to prefix the id with `app_`: `app_0840159d1af948fb8d14208e388b26ee`

It also makes it clear that this is indeed not _always_ a UUID. For instance, our AppId is a custom string, but _somtimes_ a random string (currently generated with a UUID, but that isn't fixed).
